Byzantine-Robust Clustered Federated Learning

Zhixu Tao
ORFE, Princeton University
Princeton, NJ 08544
zhixu.tao@princeton.edu &Kun Yang
ORFE, Princeton University
Princeton, NJ 08544
ky8517@princeton.edu &Sanjeev R. Kulkarni
ECE&ORFE, Princeton University
Princeton, NJ 08544
kulkarni@princeton.edu
Abstract

This paper focuses on the problem of adversarial attacks from Byzantine machines in a Federated Learning setting where non-Byzantine machines can be partitioned into disjoint clusters. In this setting, non-Byzantine machines in the same cluster have the same underlying data distribution, and different clusters of non-Byzantine machines have different learning tasks. Byzantine machines can adversarially attack any cluster and disturb the training process on clusters they attack. In the presence of Byzantine machines, the goal of our work is to identify cluster membership of non-Byzantine machines and optimize the models learned by each cluster. We adopt the Iterative Federated Clustering Algorithm (IFCA) framework of Ghosh et al. (2020) to alternatively estimate cluster membership and optimize models. In order to make this framework robust against adversarial attacks from Byzantine machines, we use coordinate-wise trimmed mean and coordinate-wise median aggregation methods used by Yin et al. (2018). Specifically, we propose a new Byzantine-Robust Iterative Federated Clustering Algorithm to improve on the results in Ghosh et al. (2019). We prove a convergence rate for this algorithm for strongly convex loss functions. We compare our convergence rate with the convergence rate of an existing algorithm, and we demonstrate the performance of our algorithm on simulated data. 111Our code is adapted from https://github.com/jichan3751/ifca, and is available at https://github.com/kun0906/brifca.

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) is a new privacy-preservation machine learning paradigm Rodríguez-Barroso et al. (2023); McMahan and Ramage (2017). Under a federated learning setting, worker machines collaboratively solve a machine learning task under the coordination of a central sever while all data remains decentralized at each worker machine Kairouz et al. (2021). The FL paradigm allows us to solve two challenges that traditional machine learning methods suffer from. The first one is the data privacy issue. In the traditional machine learning setting, training a model requires access to all data. However, some data might be personal and sensitive, for example, health data from hospitals. Federated Learning tackles this problem by not allowing the central server to have access to data held by machines. The second challenge is the growing amount of data sets and limited communication and storage capacity. In the traditional machine learning setting, the size of the training data is generally large in order to get a meaningful model. If the central sever uses data from all worker machines to solve a machine learning task, the communication between machines and central sever can be very expensive and inefficient. Moreover, storage at the server might also be an issue. Federated Learning solves this problem by machines limiting the amount of information sent to the central server.

In Federated Learning, the existence of Byzantine machines makes robustness a huge concern. Byzantine machines can adversarially manipulate the training process and corrupt the training models. It has been shown that even a single Byzantine fault may be able to change the trained model significantly Blanchard et al. (2017a). Therefore, it is important to design algorithms that are robust against adversarial attacks from Byzantine machines. This problem has been considered in a series of work Blanchard et al. (2017a, b); Yin et al. (2018); Chen et al. (2017).

Another concern in Federated Learning is the issue of data heterogeneity. In Federated Learning, worker machines often collect and generate data in a very non-identically distributed way across the network Li et al. (2020). For example, users from different countries use different languages, so in the next-word prediction task, machines are distributed in a highly non-identically distributed way. The data heterogeneity issue has been receiving more attention Kulkarni et al. (2020); Qu et al. (2022). Some research work focuses on learning one global model from non-i.i.d data Zhao et al. (2018); Mohri et al. (2019); Li et al. (2019). An alternative solution is to learn several distinct local models simultaneously Smith et al. (2017); Fallah et al. (2020); Jiang et al. (2019); Chen et al. (2018). In our work, we focus on a specific heterogeneous data setting in which worker machines can be partitioned into disjoint clusters, and each cluster learns a distinct model.

In this work, we assume a subset of machines is Byzantine. We assume non-Byzantine machines, or normal machines, can be partitioned into k𝑘k disjoint clusters based on their data distributions. Normal machines in the same cluster draw data points i.i.d from the same distribution. Different clusters correspond to different data distributions and have different learning tasks. We design a robust algorithm to cluster normal machines into k𝑘k groups and at the same time optimize models for each group. Our algorithm adopts the Iterative Federated Clustering Algorithm (IFCA) framework Ghosh et al. (2020) and uses two robust aggregation methods, namely coordinate-wise median and coordinate-wise trimmed mean Yin et al. (2018). We give assumptions on the fraction of Byzantine machines based on the worst case scenario that all Byzantine machines can collectively attack the smallest cluster. We show that even in the presence of Byzantine machines, our algorithm converges for strongly convex loss functions. Also, we do not have the assumption that all normal machines have the same number of data points. We only impose an assumption on the minimum number of data points across all normal machines. We compare our result with the convergence result of an existing algorithm and show that our algorithm achieves better error rate.

2 Related work

Clustering in Federated Learning: There is a line of work trying to solve non-i.i.d data issues in Federated Learning by clustering machines into different groups. For example, Briggs et al. (2020) introduced a hierarchical clustering step to separate clusters of machines by the similarity of their local updates to the global joint model. Sattler et al. (2020) proposed a post-processing method that is performed after a Federated Learning algorithm converges to group clients based on geometric properties of the Federated Learning loss surface. Li et al. (2021) proposed an iterative soft clustering algorithm which allows clients to be clustered into more than one cluster. Long et al. (2023) introduced a multi-center aggregation method to cluster clients, which learns multiple global models as cluster centers and simultaneously computes the optimal matching between clients and centers. Our work adopts the framework from Ghosh et al. (2020). The Iterative Federated Clustering Algorithm (IFCA) proposed by Ghosh et al. (2020) solves the problem wherein different groups of clients have their own leaning tasks. More specifically, they assume there are m𝑚m machines that can be clustered into k𝑘k disjoint clusters S1∗,…,Sk∗superscriptsubscript𝑆1…superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑘S_{1}^{*},\dots,S_{k}^{*}. These k𝑘k clusters correspond to k𝑘k different underlying distributions 𝒟1∗,…,𝒟k∗superscriptsubscript𝒟1…superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{1}^{*},\dots,\mathcal{D}_{k}^{*}. In other words, if machine i𝑖i is from cluster Sj∗superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑗S_{j}^{*}, it draws n𝑛n i.i.d data points from 𝒟j∗superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑗\mathcal{D}_{j}^{*}. In our work, we use a similar setting but with Byzantine machines. We formulate our problem in Section 3. IFCA alternatively estimates the cluster identities of clients and optimizes model parameters for each cluster.

Robustness in Federated Learning: In order to tackle adversarial attacks, there are several different directions to enhance the robustness of Federate Learning algorithms. The first method is robust aggregation. The most common way to aggregate information is by using FedAvg McMahan et al. (2017) which takes the weighted average of estimated parameters sent by machines. However, FedAvg is susceptible to outliers and adversarial attacks. Wu et al. (2020) and Pillutla et al. (2019) proposed to aggregate by using the geometric mean. Pillutla et al. (2022) used a multidimensional generalization of the median, known as geometric median or L1subscript𝐿1L_{1} median to do aggregation. Blanchard et al. (2017a) proposed an aggregation method in a distributed learning setting based on combining majority-based and squared-distance-based methods together. In our work, we adopt the aggregation method from Yin et al. (2018). In Yin et al. (2018), they proposed two robust aggregation methods, namely coordinate-wise median and coordinate-wise trimmed mean. They showed that these two aggregation methods can achieve order-optimal error rates under some conditions. It is worth of noting that during the preparation of this paper, a recent work by Zhu et al. (2023) proposes several new robust Federated Learning protocols which improve error rates from Yin et al. (2018). This recent work suggests a future direction which is discussed in Section 7. Another method to tackle adversarial attacks is to detect all Byzantine machines and put them into a separate cluster that will not participate in the training process. For example, Sattler et al. (2020) assumed a subset of machines is Byzantine and adopted the IFCA framework to cluster Byzantine machines into a separate cluster. Wang et al. (2022) proposed an algorithm called BRIEF which uses DBSCAN clustering algorithm to detect malicious machines and then implements model segmentation in each cluster to thwart attacks from malicious machines.

Robust Clustering in Federated Learning: It is worth of mentioning that clustering machines in the presence of Byzantine machines has been getting more attention in Federated Learning. Specifically, Ghosh et al. (2019) solves the exact same problem as our work. However, their algorithm is different from ours. In Ghosh et al. (2019), they designed a Three-Stage algorithm which consists of local empirical risk minimization, estimated parameters clustering and model optimization on each cluster. In other words, they solve the problem by first clustering and then optimizing. Our algorithm is essentially different since we do clustering and optimizing alternatively. We make thorough comparison in section 5.

3 Problem formulation

In this section, we give a precise formulation of our problem. We consider the problem of minimizing some empirical loss functions in a Federated Learning setting. Suppose there are m𝑚m worker machines and one center machine. We assume that among these m𝑚m worker machines, an α𝛼\alpha fraction of them are Byzantine machines while the remaining 1−α1𝛼1-\alpha fraction of machines are normal. We denote ℬℬ\mathcal{B} as the set of Byzantine machines. For those (1−α)​m1𝛼𝑚(1-\alpha)m normal machines, we assume there are k𝑘k different underlying data distributions 𝒟1∗,…,𝒟k∗superscriptsubscript𝒟1…superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{1}^{*},\dots,\mathcal{D}_{k}^{*}, and these normal machines can be clustered into k𝑘k disjoint clusters S1∗,…,Sk∗superscriptsubscript𝑆1…superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑘S_{1}^{*},\dots,S_{k}^{*}. If a normal machine i𝑖i is from cluster Sj∗superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑗S_{j}^{*}, it draws nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} i.i.d data zi,1,…,zi,nisuperscript𝑧𝑖1…superscript𝑧𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖z^{i,1},\dots,z^{i,n_{i}} from distribution 𝒟j∗superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑗\mathcal{D}_{j}^{*}. We assume that the normal machines do not know their cluster identity. Normal machines communicate with the center machine according to some predefined protocols. Let f​(θ;z):Θ→ℝ:𝑓𝜃𝑧→Θℝf(\theta;z):\Theta\rightarrow\mathbb{R} be the loss function associated with a data point z𝑧z. We assume the parameter space Θ⊂ℝdΘsuperscriptℝ𝑑\Theta\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} is convex and compact with diameter D𝐷D. We denote nm​i​n:=mini∈[m]∖ℬ⁡niassignsubscript𝑛𝑚𝑖𝑛subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑚ℬsubscript𝑛𝑖n_{min}:=\min_{i\in[m]\setminus\mathcal{B}}n_{i} as the minimum number of data points across all normal machines and N:=∑i∈[m]∖ℬniassign𝑁subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑚ℬsubscript𝑛𝑖N:=\sum_{i\in[m]\setminus\mathcal{B}}n_{i} as the total number of data points over all normal machines. Let Fj​(θ):=𝔼z∼𝒟j∗​[f​(θ;z)]assignsuperscript𝐹𝑗𝜃subscript𝔼similar-to𝑧superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑗delimited-[]𝑓𝜃𝑧F^{j}(\theta):=\mathbb{E}_{z\sim\mathcal{D}_{j}^{*}}[f(\theta;z)] be the population loss function associated with distribution 𝒟j∗superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑗\mathcal{D}_{j}^{*}. Our goal is to find a set of estimators {θj}j=1ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗𝑗1𝑘\{\theta_{j}\}_{j=1}^{k} that is close to {θj∗}j=1ksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗𝑗1𝑘\{\theta_{j}^{*}\}_{j=1}^{k} where θj∗=arg⁡minθ∈Θ⁡Fj​(θ)superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗subscript𝜃Θsuperscript𝐹𝑗𝜃\theta_{j}^{*}=\arg\min_{\theta\in\Theta}F^{j}(\theta). In order to achieve our goal, we minimize the empirical loss function associated with the i𝑖i-th normal machine Fi​(θ):=1ni​∑l=1nif​(θ;zi,l)assignsubscript𝐹𝑖𝜃1subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑙1subscript𝑛𝑖𝑓𝜃superscript𝑧𝑖𝑙F_{i}(\theta):=\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum_{l=1}^{n_{i}}f(\theta;z^{i,l}). Note that throughout the paper, we use ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\| to denote ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm.

One example of our problem formulation is mean estimation with adversarial attacks. Suppose α​m𝛼𝑚\alpha m machines are Byzantine machines and the remaining machines are normal. If a normal worker machine i𝑖i is from the j𝑗j-th cluster Sj∗superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑗S_{j}^{*}, it draws nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} i.i.d data from distribution 𝒟j∗superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑗\mathcal{D}_{j}^{*} with mean θj∗superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗\theta_{j}^{*}: zi,1,…,zi,ni∼𝒟j∗​(θj∗)similar-tosuperscript𝑧𝑖1…superscript𝑧𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗z^{i,1},\dots,z^{i,n_{i}}\sim\mathcal{D}_{j}^{*}(\theta_{j}^{*}). It’s easy to verify that θj∗superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗\theta_{j}^{*} is the minimizer of the population loss function Fj​(θ)=𝔼z∼𝒟j∗​[‖z−θ‖2]superscript𝐹𝑗𝜃subscript𝔼similar-to𝑧superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑗delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝑧𝜃2F^{j}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{z\sim\mathcal{D}_{j}^{*}}[\|z-\theta\|^{2}] for the j𝑗j-th cluster. By minimizing the empirical loss function Fi​(θ)=1ni​∑l=1ni‖zi,l−θ‖2subscript𝐹𝑖𝜃1subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑙1subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptnormsuperscript𝑧𝑖𝑙𝜃2F_{i}(\theta)=\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum_{l=1}^{n_{i}}\|z^{i,l}-\theta\|^{2} associated with the i𝑖i-th normal worker machine, we are using the sample mean to estimate the population mean.

Another example in a supervised learning setting is the case of linear models with square loss Ghosh et al. (2020). We assume for a normal machine i∈Sj∗𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑗i\in S_{j}^{*}, it has nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} feature-response pairs zi,l=(xi,l,yi,l)superscript𝑧𝑖𝑙superscript𝑥𝑖𝑙superscript𝑦𝑖𝑙z^{i,l}=(x^{i,l},y^{i,l}) and each pair satisfies yi,l=⟨xi,l,θj∗⟩+ϵi,lsuperscript𝑦𝑖𝑙superscript𝑥𝑖𝑙superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑙y^{i,l}=\langle x^{i,l},\theta_{j}^{*}\rangle+\epsilon^{i,l} where xi,l∼𝒩​(0,Id)similar-tosuperscript𝑥𝑖𝑙𝒩0subscript𝐼𝑑x^{i,l}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,I_{d}) and ϵi,l∼𝒩​(0,σ2)similar-tosuperscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑙𝒩0superscript𝜎2\epsilon^{i,l}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}) is additive noise that is independent of xi,lsuperscript𝑥𝑖𝑙x^{i,l}. The square loss function is f​(θ;z)=(y−⟨x,θ⟩)2𝑓𝜃𝑧superscript𝑦𝑥𝜃2f(\theta;z)=(y-\langle x,\theta\rangle)^{2}. It’s clear that θj∗superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗\theta_{j}^{*} is the minimizer of the population loss function Fj​(⋅)superscript𝐹𝑗⋅F^{j}(\cdot).

4 Algorithm

In this section, we present our algorithm and related definitions. Our algorithm Byzantine-Robust Iterative Federated Clustering Algorithm mainly adopts the scheme of Iterative Federated Clustering Algorithm (IFCA) Ghosh et al. (2020), alternatively minimizing loss functions and estimating cluster identities. At the same time, our algorithm uses two robust aggregation methods, coordinate-wise median and coordinate-wise trimmed mean, from Yin et al. (2018) to tackle the problem of Byzantine machines. This algorithm starts with k𝑘k initial estimated parameters {θj(0)}j=1ksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗0𝑗1𝑘\{\theta_{j}^{(0)}\}_{j=1}^{k}. At the t𝑡t-th iteration, the center machine sends the current estimated parameters {θj(t)}j=1ksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗𝑡𝑗1𝑘\{\theta_{j}^{(t)}\}_{j=1}^{k} to all worker machines. If the i𝑖i-th worker machine is a normal machine, it estimates its cluster identity by computing j^i=arg⁡minj∈[k]⁡Fi​(θj(t))subscript^𝑗𝑖subscript𝑗delimited-[]𝑘subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗𝑡\hat{j}_{i}=\arg\min_{j\in[k]}F_{i}(\theta_{j}^{(t)}), and then it computes the gradient gi=∇Fi​(θj^i(t))subscript𝑔𝑖∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜃subscript^𝑗𝑖𝑡g_{i}=\nabla F_{i}(\theta_{\hat{j}_{i}}^{(t)}) of the empirical loss function at θj^i(t)superscriptsubscript𝜃subscript^𝑗𝑖𝑡\theta_{\hat{j}_{i}}^{(t)}. Then the normal worker machine sends its current estimate j^isubscript^𝑗𝑖\hat{j}_{i} and gradient gisubscript𝑔𝑖g_{i} to the center machine. If the i𝑖i-th machine is a Byzantine machine, it can adversarially pick a j^i∈[k]subscript^𝑗𝑖delimited-[]𝑘\hat{j}_{i}\in[k] as its current estimate for cluster identity, and sends this j^isubscript^𝑗𝑖\hat{j}_{i} and an arbitrary d𝑑d dimensional vector to the center machine. After all worker machines send required information to the center machine, the center machine groups worker machines with the same cluster identity estimates into one cluster. Then the center machine has two options to aggregate gradients within one cluster. The first option is by taking the coordinate-wise median and the second option is by taking the coordinate-wise β𝛽\beta-trimmed mean of the clients’ gradients. Then the center machine updates estimated parameters for each cluster by using gradient descent. The Euclidean projection ΠΘsubscriptΠΘ\Pi_{\Theta} guarantees that the updated estimates {θj(t+1)}j=1ksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗𝑡1𝑗1𝑘\{\theta_{j}^{(t+1)}\}_{j=1}^{k} still stay in the parameter space ΘΘ\Theta. Here, the definition of coordinate-wise median and coordinate-wise trimmed mean we use is the same as Yin et al. (2018).

Definition 4.1.

(Coordinate-wise median) For a set of vectors {𝕧i}i=1m⊂ℝdsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝕧𝑖𝑖1𝑚superscriptℝ𝑑\{\mathbb{v}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{m}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}, the coordinate-wise median of these vectors is defined as a d𝑑d dimensional vector 𝕧:=med⁡{𝕧i:i∈[m]}assign𝕧med:subscript𝕧𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑚\mathbb{v}:=\operatorname{med}\{\mathbb{v}_{i}:i\in[m]\} whose hℎh-th coordinate is given by the usual one dimensional median 𝕧h:=med⁡{𝕧ih:i∈[m]}​∀h∈[d]assignsuperscript𝕧ℎmed:superscriptsubscript𝕧𝑖ℎ𝑖delimited-[]𝑚for-allℎdelimited-[]𝑑\mathbb{v}^{h}:=\operatorname{med}\{\mathbb{v}_{i}^{h}:i\in[m]\}\,\forall h\in[d].

Definition 4.2.

(Coordinate-wise trimmed mean) For a set of vectors {𝕧i}i=1m⊂ℝdsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝕧𝑖𝑖1𝑚superscriptℝ𝑑\{\mathbb{v}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{m}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} and β∈[0,12)𝛽012\beta\in[0,\frac{1}{2}), the coordinate-wise β𝛽\beta-trimmed mean is defined as a d𝑑d dimensional vector 𝕧:=trmeanβ⁡{𝕧i:i∈[m]}assign𝕧subscripttrmean𝛽:subscript𝕧𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑚\mathbb{v}:=\operatorname{trmean}_{\beta}\{\mathbb{v}_{i}:i\in[m]\} whose hℎh-th coordinate is given by 𝕧h=1(1−2​β)​m​∑v∈Uhvsuperscript𝕧ℎ112𝛽𝑚subscript𝑣subscript𝑈ℎ𝑣\mathbb{v}^{h}=\frac{1}{(1-2\beta)m}\sum_{v\in U_{h}}v where Uh⊂{𝕧ih}i=1msubscript𝑈ℎsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝕧𝑖ℎ𝑖1𝑚U_{h}\subset\{\mathbb{v}_{i}^{h}\}_{i=1}^{m} is obtained by removing the largest and smallest β𝛽\beta fraction of {𝕧ih}i=1msuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝕧𝑖ℎ𝑖1𝑚\{\mathbb{v}_{i}^{h}\}_{i=1}^{m}.

5 Theoretical guarantees

In this section, we present convergence theorems for the Byzantine-Robust IFCA algorithm presented in Section 4 and summarized in Algorithm 1. In Ghosh et al. (2020), they used a re-sampling technique to remove inter-dependence between the cluster estimation and the gradient computation. Specifically, if we run T𝑇T parallel iterations, we partition the nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} data points on the i𝑖i-th machine into 2​T2𝑇2T disjoint subsets so that each subset only contains ni′=ni2​Tsuperscriptsubscript𝑛𝑖′subscript𝑛𝑖2𝑇n_{i}^{\prime}=\frac{n_{i}}{2T} data points. We use the same technique. However, since ni′superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑖′n_{i}^{\prime} and nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} are of the same scale, for simplicity, we will just use nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} to prove theoretical results. We first introduce some definitions and assumptions we need for the convergence theorem.

Definition 5.1.

(Strong convexity) A differentiable function f:ℝd→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} is λ𝜆\lambda-strongly convex if f​(y)≥f​(x)+∇f​(x)T​(y−x)+λ2​‖y−x‖2​∀x,y∈ℝdformulae-sequence𝑓𝑦𝑓𝑥∇𝑓superscript𝑥𝑇𝑦𝑥𝜆2superscriptnorm𝑦𝑥2for-all𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ𝑑f(y)\geq f(x)+\nabla f(x)^{T}(y-x)+\frac{\lambda}{2}\|y-x\|^{2}\forall x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Definition 5.2.

(L𝐿L-smoothness) A differentiable function f:ℝd→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} is L𝐿L-smooth if ‖∇f​(x)−∇f​(y)‖≤L​‖x−y‖​∀x,y∈ℝdformulae-sequencenorm∇𝑓𝑥∇𝑓𝑦𝐿norm𝑥𝑦for-all𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ𝑑\|\nabla f(x)-\nabla f(y)\|\leq L\|x-y\|\forall x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Definition 5.3.

(Lipschitz continuity) A function f:ℝd→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} is Lipschitz continuous if there exists a constant K≥0𝐾0K\geq 0 such that ‖f​(x)−f​(y)‖≤K​‖x−y‖​∀x,y∈ℝdformulae-sequencenorm𝑓𝑥𝑓𝑦𝐾norm𝑥𝑦for-all𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ𝑑\|f(x)-f(y)\|\leq K\|x-y\|\,\forall x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Definition 5.4.

(Absolute skewness)Yin et al. (2018) For a one-dimensional random variable X𝑋X, its absolute skewness is defined as γ​(X):=𝔼​[|X−𝔼​[X]|3]Var(X)3/2\gamma(X):=\frac{\mathbb{E}[|X-\mathbb{E}[X]|^{3}]}{\operatorname{Var}(X)^{3/2}}. For a d𝑑d-dimensional random vector 𝕏=[X1​X2​…​Xd]T𝕏superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑋1subscript𝑋2…subscript𝑋𝑑𝑇\mathbb{X}=[X_{1}\,X_{2}\,\dots\,X_{d}]^{T}, its absolute skewness is defined coordinate-wise by γ​(𝕏):=[γ​(X1)​γ​(X2)​…​γ​(Xd)]Tassign𝛾𝕏superscriptdelimited-[]𝛾subscript𝑋1𝛾subscript𝑋2…𝛾subscript𝑋𝑑𝑇\gamma(\mathbb{X}):=[\gamma(X_{1})\,\gamma(X_{2})\,\dots\,\gamma(X_{d})]^{T}.

First, we impose convexity and smoothness assumptions on the loss functions f𝑓f and Fjsuperscript𝐹𝑗F^{j}.

Assumption 5.5.

The population loss function Fj​(⋅)superscript𝐹𝑗⋅F^{j}(\cdot) is λFsubscript𝜆𝐹\lambda_{F}-strongly convex and LFsubscript𝐿𝐹L_{F}-smooth ∀j∈[k]for-all𝑗delimited-[]𝑘\forall j\in[k].

Since we use loss function values to determine cluster identities of normal machines, we also need the following distributional assumptions on f​(θ;z)𝑓𝜃𝑧f(\theta;z).

5.1 Coordinate-wise median analysis

For coordinate-wise median analysis, we need the following assumptions on the variance of the gradient and absolute skewness. As noted in Yin et al. (2018), these two assumptions are satisfied in many learning problems.

Assumption 5.9.

(Bounded variance of gradient) ∀j∈[k],∀θ∈Θformulae-sequencefor-all𝑗delimited-[]𝑘for-all𝜃Θ\forall j\in[k],\,\forall\theta\in\Theta, the variance of ∇f​(θ;z)∇𝑓𝜃𝑧\nabla f(\theta;z) is bounded where z∼𝒟j∗similar-to𝑧superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑗z\sim\mathcal{D}_{j}^{*}, i.e., ∃ν2superscript𝜈2\exists\,\nu^{2} such that 𝔼z∼𝒟j∗​[‖∇f​(θ;z)−∇Fj​(θ)‖2]≤ν2subscript𝔼similar-to𝑧superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑗delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇𝑓𝜃𝑧∇superscript𝐹𝑗𝜃2superscript𝜈2\mathbb{E}_{z\sim\mathcal{D}_{j}^{*}}[\|\nabla f(\theta;z)-\nabla F^{j}(\theta)\|^{2}]\leq\nu^{2}.

Assumption 5.10.

(Bounded absolute skewness) ∀j∈[k],∀θ∈Θformulae-sequencefor-all𝑗delimited-[]𝑘for-all𝜃Θ\forall j\in[k],\,\forall\theta\in\Theta, ∃S>0𝑆0\exists S>0 such that ‖γ​(∇f​(θ;z))‖∞≤Ssubscriptnorm𝛾∇𝑓𝜃𝑧𝑆\|\gamma(\nabla f(\theta;z))\|_{\infty}\leq S where z∼𝒟j∗similar-to𝑧superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑗z\sim\mathcal{D}_{j}^{*}.

5.2 Coordinate-wise trimmed mean analysis

Next, we present the convergence theorem for the algorithm with Option II, trimmed mean aggregation. We need the following sub-exponential property for the coordinate-wise trimmed mean. Compared with the bounded absolute skewness from assumption 5.10 for the coordinate-wise median, the sub-exponential property is stronger since it requires all the moments of the partial derivatives are bounded.

Assumption 5.12.

(σ𝜎\sigma-sub-exponential) ∀h∈[d]for-allℎdelimited-[]𝑑\forall h\in[d] and ∀θ∈Θfor-all𝜃Θ\forall\theta\in\Theta, ∂hf​(θ;z)subscriptℎ𝑓𝜃𝑧\partial_{h}f(\theta;z) is σ𝜎\sigma-sub-exponential.

Again, the assumption on α𝛼\alpha is based on the worst case scenario that all Byzantine machines can collectively attack the smallest cluster.

5.3 Comparison with existing algorithm

It is important to compare our result with the result of the Three-Stage Algorithm from Ghosh et al. (2019). The Three-Stage Algorithm consists of empirical risk minimization, robust clustering of Empirical Risk Minimizers (ERMs), and robust aggregation. Specifically, we analyze the performance of this algorithm when Trimmed K𝐾K-means Clustering Algorithm is used at the second stage and coordinate-wise trimmed mean is used at the third stage. We re-define notations from Ghosh et al. (2019). Suppose all machines have the same number of data points n𝑛n. We define GSsubscript𝐺𝑆G_{S} as the maximum fraction of mis-clustered points in a cluster after S𝑆S clustering iterations at stage II. With high probability, suppose GS≤ρsubscript𝐺𝑆𝜌G_{S}\leq\rho. Define α~j=ρ​pj+αpj+αsubscript~𝛼𝑗𝜌subscript𝑝𝑗𝛼subscript𝑝𝑗𝛼\tilde{\alpha}_{j}=\frac{\rho p_{j}+\alpha}{p_{j}+\alpha}. Then according to Theorem 2 from Ghosh et al. (2019), the error rate for the j𝑗j-th estimate is ‖θ^j−θj∗‖≤𝒪~​(α~j​dn+dpj​m​n)normsubscript^𝜃𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗~𝒪subscript~𝛼𝑗𝑑𝑛𝑑subscript𝑝𝑗𝑚𝑛\|\hat{\theta}_{j}-\theta_{j}^{*}\|\leq\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(\frac{\tilde{\alpha}_{j}d}{\sqrt{n}}+\frac{d}{\sqrt{p_{j}mn}}). However, this error rate is comparable with our error rate only when k=2𝑘2k=2 and the parameters {θ1∗,θ2∗}superscriptsubscript𝜃1superscriptsubscript𝜃2\{\theta_{1}^{*},\theta_{2}^{*}\} satisfy θ1∗=−θ2∗superscriptsubscript𝜃1superscriptsubscript𝜃2\theta_{1}^{*}=-\theta_{2}^{*}. In this case, after 3​log⁡m3𝑚3\log m steps in stage II, the maximum mis-clustering rate ρ𝜌\rho can be 0. Here, α~j=αpj+αsubscript~𝛼𝑗𝛼subscript𝑝𝑗𝛼\tilde{\alpha}_{j}=\frac{\alpha}{p_{j}+\alpha}. Since pjsubscript𝑝𝑗p_{j} is typically much larger than α𝛼\alpha, we have α~j≈αpj≤αpsubscript~𝛼𝑗𝛼subscript𝑝𝑗𝛼𝑝\tilde{\alpha}_{j}\approx\frac{\alpha}{p_{j}}\leq\frac{\alpha}{p}. This gives an error rate 𝒪~​(α​dp​n+dp​m​n)~𝒪𝛼𝑑𝑝𝑛𝑑𝑝𝑚𝑛\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(\frac{\alpha d}{p\sqrt{n}}+\frac{d}{\sqrt{pmn}}), which is the same as our error rate. When k𝑘k is large, the error rate will have an extra dependence on d2p2​nsuperscript𝑑2superscript𝑝2𝑛\frac{d^{2}}{p^{2}\sqrt{n}}. See Appendix C for detailed analysis. The sub-optimal error rate is due to the sub-optimal performance of Trimmed K𝐾K-means Clustering Algorithm in high dimension. Moreover, in the Three-Stage Algorithm, after the second clustering stage, the clustering result is fixed and clustering mistake will not be corrected after the second stage, while in our algorithm, we re-cluster at every iteration adaptively based on new estimates.

In Ghosh et al. (2019), the convergence result is guaranteed under a stronger assumption that the empirical risk minimizers {θ^(i)}i=1(1−α)​msuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript^𝜃𝑖𝑖11𝛼𝑚\{\hat{\theta}^{(i)}\}_{i=1}^{(1-\alpha)m} corresponding to non-Byzantine machines are sampled from a mixture of k𝑘k σ𝜎\sigma-sub-gaussian distributions. One example that violates this assumption is the mean estimation problem for Poisson distributions.

Consider k𝑘k Poisson distributions Pois⁡(λj∗)Poissuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝑗\operatorname{Pois}(\lambda_{j}^{*}) with unknown parameters λj∗superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑗\lambda_{j}^{*}. If a normal machine i𝑖i is from cluster Sj∗superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑗S_{j}^{*}, it draws nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} i.i.d data points xi,1,…,xi,nisuperscript𝑥𝑖1…superscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖x^{i,1},\dots,x^{i,n_{i}} from Pois⁡(λj∗)Poissuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝑗\operatorname{Pois}(\lambda_{j}^{*}). Suppose we use the standard squared loss function f​(λ,x)=‖x−λ‖2𝑓𝜆𝑥superscriptnorm𝑥𝜆2f(\lambda,x)=\|x-\lambda\|^{2}. The empirical risk minimizer is given by the sample mean x¯i=1ni​∑l=1nixi,lsubscript¯𝑥𝑖1subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑙1subscript𝑛𝑖superscript𝑥𝑖𝑙\bar{x}_{i}=\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum_{l=1}^{n_{i}}x^{i,l} which follows 1ni​Pois⁡(ni​λj∗)1subscript𝑛𝑖Poissubscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑗\frac{1}{n_{i}}\operatorname{Pois}(n_{i}\lambda_{j}^{*}). It does not have the sub-Gaussian property.

6 Experiments

In this section, we present results of our experiments. For the experiments, we assume all machines have the same number of data points n=100𝑛100n=100. We begin with experiments on a mixture of linear models with standard squared loss functions. We first generate ground truth parameters, or linear regression coefficients, {θj∗}j=1ksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗𝑗1𝑘\{\theta_{j}^{*}\}_{j=1}^{k} by drawing θj∗∼Bernoulli⁡(0.5)similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗Bernoulli0.5\theta_{j}^{*}\sim\operatorname{Bernoulli}(0.5) coordinate-wise ∀j∈[k]for-all𝑗delimited-[]𝑘\forall j\in[k]. We re-scale all parameters such that ‖θj∗‖2=1​∀j∈[k]subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗21for-all𝑗delimited-[]𝑘\|\theta_{j}^{*}\|_{2}=1\,\forall j\in[k]. For (1−α)​m1𝛼𝑚(1-\alpha)m non-Byzantine machines, we distribute them evenly in each cluster so that each cluster has (1−α)​mk1𝛼𝑚𝑘\frac{(1-\alpha)m}{k} non-Byzantine machines. For the i𝑖i-th non-Byzantine machine in the j𝑗j-th cluster, we generate data points {(xi,l,yi,l)}l=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖𝑙superscript𝑦𝑖𝑙𝑙1𝑛\{(x^{i,l},y^{i,l})\}_{l=1}^{n} by yi,l=θj∗T​xi,l+ϵi,lsuperscript𝑦𝑖𝑙superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗absent𝑇superscript𝑥𝑖𝑙superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑙y^{i,l}=\theta_{j}^{*T}x^{i,l}+\epsilon^{i,l} where xi,l∼𝒩​(0,Id)similar-tosuperscript𝑥𝑖𝑙𝒩0subscript𝐼𝑑x^{i,l}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,I_{d}) and ϵi,l∼𝒩​(0,σ2)similar-tosuperscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑙𝒩0superscript𝜎2\epsilon^{i,l}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}) are independent. For a Byzantine machine b𝑏b, we still sample its regression coefficient θbsubscript𝜃𝑏\theta_{b} by θb∼Bernoulli⁡(0.5)similar-tosubscript𝜃𝑏Bernoulli0.5\theta_{b}\sim\operatorname{Bernoulli}(0.5) coordinate-wise, but we re-scale it so that ‖θb‖2=3subscriptnormsubscript𝜃𝑏23\|\theta_{b}\|_{2}=3 to make outliers. Then for the b𝑏b-th Byzantine machine, its data points {(xb,l,yb,l)}l=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑏𝑙superscript𝑦𝑏𝑙𝑙1𝑛\{(x^{b,l},y^{b,l})\}_{l=1}^{n} are generated by yb,l=θbT​xb,l+ϵb,l,xb,l∼𝒩​(0,Id),ϵb,l∼𝒩​(0,σ2)formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑦𝑏𝑙superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑏𝑇superscript𝑥𝑏𝑙superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏𝑙formulae-sequencesimilar-tosuperscript𝑥𝑏𝑙𝒩0subscript𝐼𝑑similar-tosuperscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏𝑙𝒩0superscript𝜎2y^{b,l}=\theta_{b}^{T}x^{b,l}+\epsilon^{b,l},x^{b,l}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,I_{d}),\epsilon^{b,l}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}).

At the t𝑡t-th iteration, after the center machine sends current estimates {θj(t)}j=1ksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗𝑡𝑗1𝑘\{\theta_{j}^{(t)}\}_{j=1}^{k}, each non-Byzantine machine uses loss function values to determine which cluster it belongs to, and computes its gradient. For each Byzantine machine, it also uses loss function values to determine which cluster it belongs to, but for gradient computation, it computes its gradient at 3​θj(t)3superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗𝑡3\theta_{j}^{(t)} so that the gradient it sends back to the center machine will become an outlier again.

We run three different algorithms. The first one is Algorithm 1 with both aggregation options, coordinate-wise median and coordinate wise trimmed mean, for 300 iterations. The second one is the IFCA Algorithm Ghosh et al. (2020) (using FedAvgFedAvg\operatorname{FedAvg} for aggregation) for 300 iterations. The third one is the Three-Stage Algorithm Ghosh et al. (2019) with Trimmed K𝐾K-means Clustering Algorithm for 100 iterations and coordinate-wise trimmed mean aggregation for 300 iterations. We define dist=1k​∑j=1k‖θ^j−θj∗‖dist1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑘normsubscript^𝜃𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗\operatorname{dist}=\frac{1}{k}\sum_{j=1}^{k}\|\hat{\theta}_{j}-\theta_{j}^{*}\| as our evaluation metric where {θ^j}j=1ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript^𝜃𝑗𝑗1𝑘\{\hat{\theta}_{j}\}_{j=1}^{k} are estimated parameters obtained from the algorithms. The three algorithms are run in the following 4 settings: (a) k=2,m=80formulae-sequence𝑘2𝑚80k=2,m=80, (b) k=5,m=200formulae-sequence𝑘5𝑚200k=5,m=200, (c) k=10,m=400formulae-sequence𝑘10𝑚400k=10,m=400, and (d) k=15,m=600formulae-sequence𝑘15𝑚600k=15,m=600. For all settings, the fraction of Byzantine machines is α=0.05𝛼0.05\alpha=0.05 and the fraction of trimmed points in the trimmed-mean aggregation is β=0.05𝛽0.05\beta=0.05. The noise scale is σ2=0.2superscript𝜎20.2\sigma^{2}=0.2. Also, we run each setting for d=[20,50,100,200,500]𝑑2050100200500d=[20,50,100,200,500]. For each experiment, we run 50 trails.

In Figure 1(a) and 1(b), we plot the average distdist\operatorname{dist} over 50 trails with respect to the dimension d𝑑d for k=5𝑘5k=5 and k=10𝑘10k=10. When d𝑑d is small, for example, d=20𝑑20d=20 or d=50𝑑50d=50, the Three-Stage Algorithm performs the best. However, when d𝑑d becomes larger, the Three-Stage Algorithm performs the worst. This is due to the performance of the Trimmed K𝐾K-means Clustering Algorithm used at the second clustering stage. When the dimension is low, the Trimmed K𝐾K-means Clustering Algorithm can guarantee good clustering result, while in high dimension, the final clustering result is sub-optimal. We also observe that the IFCA with FedAvgFedAvg\operatorname{FedAvg} in general performs worse than Algorithm 1. This is due to the fact that FedAvgFedAvg\operatorname{FedAvg} is not robust against Byzantine machines. In Figure 1(c), we plot the average distdist\operatorname{dist} over 50 trails with respect to the number of clusters k=[2,5,10,15]𝑘251015k=[2,5,10,15]. In general, when k𝑘k becomes larger, all algorithms perform worse, which validates the point that the error rate has dependence on the minimum fraction of cluster size p𝑝p. In our experiments, p=1k𝑝1𝑘p=\frac{1}{k}. In conclusion, these plots validate our comparison result in Section 5.3 that the Three-Stage Algorithm gives an extra dependence on d2p2​nsuperscript𝑑2superscript𝑝2𝑛\frac{d^{2}}{p^{2}\sqrt{n}}. Therefore, when the dimension is high or when the number of clusters is large, Algorithm 1 outperforms the Three-Stage algorithm. Moreover, with existence of Byzantine machines, Algorithm 1 outperforms the IFCA framework.

7 Limitations and future directions

As mentioned earlier in Section 5, the first limitation of our algorithm is that the dependence on dimension d𝑑d may lead to sub-optimal performance for high dimensional learning problems. The recent paper Zhu et al. (2023), which studies Byzantine problems in non-clustering setting (k=1𝑘1k=1), proposes several new Byzantine-Robust Federated Learning protocols which improve the dimension dependence and achieve nearly optimal statistical rate with milder assumptions. They also prove a statistical lower bound Ω​(αn+dm​n)Ω𝛼𝑛𝑑𝑚𝑛\Omega(\sqrt{\frac{\alpha}{n}+\frac{d}{mn}}). It might be interesting to extend our work and solve the dimension dependence problem by using their new Byzantine-Robust protocols. Moreover, we would like to prove a statistical lower bound for clustering problem with Byzantine machines. A second limitation of our work is the strict requirement of initialization. One approach to address this problem may be to have the machines first send some information to initialize the algorithm.

Appendix

Appendix A Proof of Theorem 5.11

Our proof is modified based on proofs from Yin et al. [2018] and Ghosh et al. [2020]. The proof of the theorem consists of two parts. First, we prove at the t𝑡t-th step, if the estimate θj(t)subscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑡𝑗\theta^{(t)}_{j} is close enough to θj∗superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗\theta_{j}^{*}, the estimate for the j𝑗j-th cluster will also be close to Sj∗superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑗S_{j}^{*}. Second, we prove conversely when the estimate for the j𝑗j-th cluster is close enough to Sj∗superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑗S_{j}^{*} at the t𝑡t-th step, θj(t+1)subscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑡1𝑗\theta^{(t+1)}_{j} will be close enough to θj∗superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗\theta_{j}^{*}. We start with one-step analysis.

A.1 One-step analysis

Suppose at the t𝑡t-th step, we have ‖θj(t)−θj∗‖≤14​λFLF​Δ​∀j∈[k]normsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗14subscript𝜆𝐹subscript𝐿𝐹Δfor-all𝑗delimited-[]𝑘\|\theta_{j}^{(t)}-\theta_{j}^{*}\|\leq\frac{1}{4}\sqrt{\frac{\lambda_{F}}{L_{F}}}\Delta\,\forall j\in[k]. We define Sj(t):={i∈[m]:j^i(t)=j}assignsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑗𝑡conditional-set𝑖delimited-[]𝑚superscriptsubscript^𝑗𝑖𝑡𝑗S_{j}^{(t)}:=\{i\in[m]:\hat{j}_{i}^{(t)}=j\} as the set of worker machines clustered into the j𝑗j-th cluster at the t𝑡t-th step. Furthermore, we define Eij,j′superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑖𝑗superscript𝑗′E_{i}^{j,j^{\prime}} for a normal worker machine i𝑖i from cluster Sj∗superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑗S_{j}^{*} as an event of i𝑖i being clustered into cluster Sj′(t)superscriptsubscript𝑆superscript𝑗′𝑡S_{j^{\prime}}^{(t)}. If j=j′𝑗superscript𝑗′j=j^{\prime}, Eij,j′superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑖𝑗superscript𝑗′E_{i}^{j,j^{\prime}} denotes the event of i𝑖i-th normal worker machine being clustered correctly. Otherwise, it’s the event of i𝑖i-th normal worker machine being mis-clustered.

A.2 Proof of Claim A.2

The proof for Claim A.2 is modified based on the proof of Claim 2 in Yin et al. [2018]. The main modification is for Lemma 1 in Yin et al. [2018].

Appendix B Proof of Theorem 5.13

The proof of Theorem 5.13 essentially has the same structure as proof for Theorem 5.11. The first part is still to prove at the t𝑡t-th step, if the estimate θj(t)subscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑡𝑗\theta^{(t)}_{j} is close to θj∗superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗\theta_{j}^{*}, the estimate for the j𝑗j-th cluster is also close to Sj∗superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑗S_{j}^{*}. B.2 Proof of Claim B.1

The proof for Claim B.1 is modified based on the proof of Claim 5 from Yin et al. [2018]. First recall Bernstein’s inequality for independent sub-exponential random variables.

Claim B.2.

(Bernstein’s inequality) Let X1,…,XNsubscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑁X_{1},\dots,X_{N} be independent, mean zero and σisubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i}-sub-exponential random variables. Then ∀t≥0for-all𝑡0\forall t\geq 0,

ℙ​(|1N​∑i=1NXi|≥t)≤2​exp⁡(−N​min⁡{t22​(maxi⁡σi)2,t2​maxi⁡σi}).ℙ1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑋𝑖𝑡2𝑁superscript𝑡22superscriptsubscript𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖2𝑡2subscript𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖\mathbb{P}(|\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}X_{i}|\geq t)\leq 2\exp(-N\min\{\frac{t^{2}}{2(\max_{i}\sigma_{i})^{2}},\frac{t}{2\max_{i}\sigma_{i}}\}).

We use Bernstein’s inequality to prove the following lemma.
